title: John Newton Johnson to Walt Whitman, [19 February] 1875
text: Meltonsville, AlAlabama 1875. Mr. Whitman— was received a few days ago. I had examined that writing for a while correspondence except my son in I would wait a good long spell, I to learn how much of purely spontaneous you do fear in the (of choice) humble strange manner living down here in also was curious to see if you would graciously be sending me and little Walt the new volume which you are to bring out this summer. But getting with yours the picture of John Burroughs, I suppose it will be perhaps enough to write now. ☞ I have no faith in Physiognomy Physiognomy as a practical if in any way, but the the book seem fully indicative of talent tho' perhaps strongly expresses than an greater share of which I glory in trust in . Perhaps tho' he is way. sometimes doubted this something well, he is too ", other times "well, he is very honest."—However, if now, or about to be "on the banks of one of the noblest and most fruitful rivers" (poetical namesake of our old son) there is a "similarity and J.B.—I had the honor to say introducing fine Apples and Pears backwoods county. Bartlett, Lucrative, and L.B. Jersey unknown 'till Williams came to the . Ah! Those fine fruits were the only I could have for some years after the end of the war. They and "Leaves of Grass" have stood alone in making me Jubilant. My interest, profit and pleasure have been much distracted by fruit-rotting so generally years. But memory's pleasures can some degree.But getting you and me, dear comforter ughs hints at you ing to low, whenever you go, and meetings with friends or letters or sights of "show (Centennial or what not) or sort or source—to you still and can yet love that case for between this while I earnestly and you should take no interest that which cause you one bit or anxiety if bad luck should befall in any way— still, myself, children my not enthusible and mostly wife are delighted, flattered, and feel ourselves highly distinguished any time we get anything of any sort from Uncle Walt or big Walt Whitman as the children say. (My & Wife's dreadful "tempers" may wreck us any time—so care not much for us. We are doing finely in all our farming operations. Health tolerably good. Little Walt came to us after about twice the usual may have helped some, but mostly lingered over so long and caused us all to threefold pride and of what had to get over—the and a "back-heart —If I shall not write much again for a good long time, please excuse me, and on the other hand (looking at the be so foolish as to write too much (which I hope I shall not) then excuse that, and your shine conspicuous.J.N.JSince writing the above, I first notice the red chalk mark alongside the lines where Burroughs invites "George" (who is "George?") to come there and look at a that is for sale. Knowing how some of you northern people wish to run from your winters, I will say is "George" of a Southern as a ? I would not recommend my section for a Northern man to a fortune except in raising clover or other hay.
